title: Boolean Variables (true or false)
simplifierConcept:
Sometimes you need to store a YES or NO answer. Is the player alive? Is the door locked? Is the game over?

That's where BOOLEAN variables come in! A boolean (named after mathematician George Boole) can only hold two values:

• true (yes, on, correct)
• false (no, off, incorrect)

Think of a boolean like a light switch – it's either ON or OFF, nothing in between!

In C#, we use the 'bool' type for these. Booleans are INCREDIBLY powerful for making decisions in programs (you'll see this soon when we learn 'if statements').

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: 'bool' is the type for true/false values. Notice: NO QUOTES around true! true and false are special keywords in C#.
These are NOT strings! Don't write "true" – just write true. They're built-in values that C# understands.
Boolean variables often start with 'is', 'has', or 'can' (like isReady, hasPermission, canJump) because they answer yes/no questions.

challenge.instructions:
Create a character status display! Make variables for:
1. isHungry (boolean) - set to true
2. isTired (boolean) - set to false
3. energy (int) - set to 75
4. name (string) - set to any name

Display all of them in a formatted status report!
challenge.hint: Remember: true and false have NO QUOTES! Write bool isHungry = true; not bool isHungry = "true";
commonStickingPoints: Putting quotes around true/false: bool isReady = "true"; is WRONG! Use bool isReady = true; (no quotes!)
Capitalizing true/false: C# is case-sensitive! Use true, not True or TRUE.
Trying to assign other values: bool can ONLY hold true or false, nothing else!
